items.title: Changed log level for server start
items.body: When server start throws an error, it now logs as `Log.error` instead of `Log.info`

items.title: fix documentation + whitespace
items.body:
This PR standardizes the documentation and whitespace style throughout the project.

It also makes a few minor changes like throwing `Abort.InvalidParameter` for more information about why the type-safe routing didn't match.

items.title: App Refactor
items.body: `Application.workDir` and `View.resourceDir` are no longer static + added convenience base `Controller` class along with `Application.view()` to make working without the static vars easier.

items.body: Made vapor cli a bit safer to address concerns in #157

items.title: validation
items.body:
Validation proposal.

I added some updates that I think achieves some good syntax compromises between type safety, and basic accessors. I think we should discuss a lot of it, but here's the main points.
## Example

``` Swift
class UserName: ValidationSuite {
    static func validate(input value: String) -> Bool {
        // composing validators. Can also be done inline
        let evaluation = OnlyAlphanumeric.self
            + StringLength.min(5)
            + StringLength.max(20)

        return evaluation.validate(value)
    }
}
```

Now Use

``` Swift
let username = try possibleName.validated(by: UserName.self)
```

or w/ type inference

``` Swift
class User {
    let username: Validated<UserName>

    init(username: String) throws {
        self.username = try username.validated()
    }
}
```
## Naming Conventions:

Some of the conventions I'm trying to stick to are as follows
### tested

Returns `Self` type, ie: `String` returns `String`, `Int` returns `Int`, etc. This is useful if one wants to incorporate validators, but not the `Validated<V>` type.

``` Swift
// tested is String
let tested = try "someString".tested(by: ValidatorOne + ValidatorTwo || ValidatorThree)
```
### passes

Returns `Bool` whether or not a value is valid. I think I'd prefer to remove this, but I'm not sure if others think it has value.
### validated

This validates the input and creates a `Validated<V>` object that within reason can ensure the validity of the underlying value throughout its life.

``` Swift
// Validated<Username>
let name = try "possibleName".validated(by: Username.self)
// Validated<And<Email, StringLength>>
let googleEmail = try "possible@email.com".validated(by: Email.from("google.com") + StringLength.min(13)) // Pretending google doesn't allow 1 or 2 letter emails (@google.com + 3)
```
## Composition

Validators can be easily composed together on the fly w/ logical operators `!`, `||`, and `+` or `&&`. 

``` Swift
let secureEntry = try input.validated(by: StringLenght.min(5) + ContainsNumber.self || ContainsPunctuation.self)
```
#### Minor Annoyance

A lot of functions are based on `Validatable`. If a user wants a custom Validator, they need to make the `InputType` conform to `Validatable` with:

``` Swift
extension CustomType: Validatable {}
```

It's simple to do, but a minor annoyance. This is what allows a flexible syntax w/o redeclaring the same functions for new types. Although it's annoying, I think it's better to the alternative. 
#### Value Safety

We had to sacrifice a bit of the value safety in order to have more dynamic validators. I think this is a good mix of the two concepts.

\- `ValidationSuite` which uses a class level initializer and can be more authoritative. This can't take parameters, but is a little bit stricter.

\- `Validator` initialized instance that takes parameters, but is slightly less safe. For example, `Validated<StringLength>` requires an instance of string length. We can guarantee the value has been validated by length, but we can't know the parameters passed. There is talk of eventually being able to do something like `StringLength<5>`. We should revisit this type when/if that becomes possible
## Discussion Points
- [x] Syntax. Do we like the way this looks
- [x] Naming Conventions, `tested`, `validated`, `passes`
- [x] Validatable Syntax. Possible alternatives
- [x] Operators. Should we include operators?
- [x] Should we keep them? Should use `+` or `&&` or both?

items.title: Resolves an infinite loop when receiving data
items.body:
Per the system recv API if the other side of the connection returns 0 bytes the peer has performed an orderly shutdown. Because of this, if Hummingbird's receive returns an empty array, that indicates the connection is closed properly. This updates Vapor code to respect that condition and not continue to loop if the peer is closed.

This issue is causing servers to run at full load. Special thanks to linode for alerting me haha.

items.title: New Snapshot - 04-12
items.body:
You can test w/ this dependency:

``` Swift
.Package(url: "https://github.com/LoganWright/vapor.git", majorVersion: 0, minor: 6)
```

items.title: Added missing "else" in example guard statement
Reimplement action routing
items.body: The original implementation for this got lost somewhere. This adds it back in with tests.

items.title: Resolves a leak when creating timestamps for responses
items.body:
Each response we send back we're leaking memory from the timestamp we generate. This fixes it by deallocating the memory we allocate for building the timestamp. I ran Vapor through the Leaks instrument before the fix and after with `ab` hitting it, and this fixes it. No other leaks we're found. 👍 

@LoganWright This was the leak I mentioned yesterday to you.

items.title: Adopt new Hummingbird sockets
items.body: I wanted to structure the types in Hummingbird a bit more to allow more robust conformances to C7. Now we have a basic Socket type that handles sending and receiving data, and a ServerSocket that provides the functionality to bind, listen, and accept sockets. There's also a ClientSocket that can perform connections, but that doesn't affect Vapor at all.

items.title: Snapshot 5 3
items.body:
Adds support for the May 3rd snapshot.

Changes `app.server` from `lazy Server` to `Server?`

We will need to update the documentation for this change and consider how it affects the public API. 

This PR contains breaking changes and will require a minor bump.

items.title: content type fix
items.body:
Deduces content types for a given file extension.

For example:

```
"css": "text/css"
```

Fixes #192

items.title: session token fix
items.body:
Currently, session tokens are only generated if no session token was provided. This allows for unused session tokens passed by the client, such as `"abc"`, to be used.

This PR enforces session token generation by the session driver. 

It does this by adding a method to the `SessionDriver` protocol `contains(identifier: String) -> Bool` and checking in the middleware if the given identifier is in the driver before opening the session.

Fixes #193
